attributes.title: Administrative burden, democratic intentions and trust in public institutions

summary.value:
DESCRIPTION:
An experimental investigation of the effects of administrative burden on unemployment insurance recipients’ intentions for democratic participation and trust in public institutions.

DATA COLLECTION STATUS:
Yes, data collection started on 09.03.2020.

DATA ACCESS STATUS:
The authors will not have any access to the data until 01.04.2020.

OTHER COMMENTS:
1) Main research questions to be investigated in this study:
- RQ1: Does administrative burden in the unemployment system shape recipients’ intentions for democratic participation?
- RQ2: Does administrative burden in the unemployment system shape recipients’ trust in public institutions?

2) Data collection:
- A survey has been distributed using SurveyXact with email invitations being sent to 10.000 Danish recipients of unemployment insurance (‘dagpenge’). All respondents are members of the same Danish unemployment insurance fund [the fund’s identity is anonymized, red.]. Invitations were sent on the day of this registration (March 9, 2020) and the authors will not have access to data until April 1, 2020.

3) Key independent variables:
We experimentally vary written assignments about experiences of administrative burden in the unemployment insurance system among unemployment insurance recipients. The respondents are asked to do a written task about one of four different themes. In the first, respondents are asked to describe a situation where the system has imposed time burdens. In the second, the respondents are asked to describe a situation where the system has limited their individual autonomy. In the third, they are asked to describe a situation where the system has lacked functionality. The fourth assignment functions as a control condition where the respondents are asked to describe their typical means of and experiences with transportation. 
The assignment to one of these four conditions is our independent variable. The survey experiment thus contains four groups. We use a between subjects design. Using the Excel randomizer, respondents are randomly assigned to group 1, group 2, group 3, or group 4. Respondents are going to see the Danish wordings of the experimental material and dependent variables below.

Group 1 (time burdens):
Som dagpengemodtager er man i løbende kontakt med dagpengesystemet. De fleste ledige vil kunne pege på både gode og dårlige oplevelser med den kontakt. Her er vi interesserede i at høre om dine dårlige oplevelser.
Nogle dagpengemodtagere oplever, at de bruger unødvendig meget tid på systemet (f.eks. transporttid, ventetid, møder og tidskrævende aktiviteter i hverdagen). I hvor høj grad kan du genkende oplevelsen af dagpengesystemet som unødvendigt tidskrævende?
1.	Slet ikke
2.	I lille grad
3.	I nogen grad
4.	I høj grad
5.	I meget høj grad
Vi vil bede dig tænke tilbage på dine oplevelser og beskrive en situation, hvor dagpengesystemet har brugt unødvendigt meget af din tid. Vi vil bede dig bruge et par minutter på at beskrive situationen i så mange detaljer som muligt.
[åbent svar]

Group 2 (autonomy loss):
Som dagpengemodtager er man i løbende kontakt med dagpengesystemet. De fleste ledige vil kunne pege på både gode og dårlige oplevelser med den kontakt. Her er vi interesserede i at høre om dine dårlige oplevelser.
Nogle dagpengemodtagere oplever, at systemets krav og regler tvinger dem til at gøre ting, de ikke har lyst til (f.eks. aktivering og mødedeltagelse) og afholder dem fra at gøre ting, de har lyst til (f.eks. frivilligt arbejde og adgang til ferie). I hvor høj grad kan du genkende oplevelsen af dagpengesystemet som tvingende og/eller begrænsende?
[Slet ikke til I meget høj grad]

Vi vil bede dig tænke tilbage på dine oplevelser og beskrive en situation, hvor systemet har tvunget dig til at gøre ting, du ikke havde lyst til, eller har afholdt dig fra at gøre noget, du havde lyst til. Vi vil bede dig bruge et par minutter på at beskrive situationen i så mange detaljer som muligt.
[åbent svar]

Group 3 (lack of functionality):
Som dagpengemodtager er man i løbende kontakt med dagpengesystemet. De fleste ledige vil kunne pege på både gode og dårlige oplevelser med den kontakt. Her er vi interesserede i at høre om dine dårlige oplevelser.
Nogle dagpengemodtagere oplever at skulle overholde krav og regler, der ikke giver mening i deres konkrete situation. Det kan f.eks. være regler og krav, der ikke tager højde for måden arbejdsmarkedet fungerer, eller regler, der ikke umiddelbart tjener noget jobrettet formål (”regler for reglernes skyld”). I hvor høj grad kan du genkende oplevelsen af at skulle overholde regler, der ikke giver mening for dig og din situation?
[Slet ikke til I meget høj grad]
Vi vil bede dig tænke tilbage på dine oplevelser og beskrive en situation, hvor dagpengesystemets krav eller regler ikke har givet mening for dig. Vi vil bede dig bruge et par minutter på at beskrive situationen i så mange detaljer som muligt.
[åbent svar]

Group 4 (Control):
[A-kasses navn, red.] medlemmer bor over hele landet, men ikke alle medlemmer har lige let ved at transportere sig rundt. Nogle har gode transportmuligheder og andre har ikke.
 
Derfor vil vi bede dig tænke på en typisk uge. Hvilke transportmidler bruger du mest og i hvilken forbindelse? Vi vil bede dig bruge et par minutter på at besvare spørgsmålet i så mange detaljer som muligt.
[åbent svar]

4) Key dependent variables:
a. Hvis der var Folketingsvalg i morgen, ville jeg helt sikkert stemme
1.	Meget uenig
2.	Uenig
3.	Hverken enig eller uenig
4.	Enig
5.	Meget enig

b. Nu kommer nogle spørgsmål om dit syn på udvalgte danske samfundsinstitutioner. På en skala fra 0 (slet ingen tillid) til 10 (fuld tillid), hvor stor tillid har du personligt til hver af de følgende institutioner?
-	b1: Regeringen
                 1 = Slet ingen tillid … 10 = Fuld tillid
-	b2: Folketinget
                 1 = Slet ingen tillid … 10 = Fuld tillid
-	b3: Retssystemet
                 1 = Slet ingen tillid … 10 = Fuld tillid
-	b4: Den offentlige sektor
                 1 = Slet ingen tillid … 10 = Fuld tillid
-	b5: Medierne
                 1 = Slet ingen tillid … 10 = Fuld tillid

c. Når du tænker på dit dagpengeforløb fremover, hvor enig eller uenig er du i følgende udsagn? 
-	c1: Jeg vil deltage aktivt i diskussioner om dagpengesystemet (fx på internettet)
                 1= Meget uenig … 5 = Meget enig
-	c2: Jeg vil arbejde på at gøre andre opmærksomme på urimeligheder og problemer i dagpengesystemet  
                 1= Meget uenig … 5 = Meget enig
-	c3: Jeg vil kontakte politikere og andre beslutningstagere om de problemer, jeg oplever i dagpengessystemet
                 1= Meget uenig … 5 = Meget enig
-	c4: Mine oplevelser i dagpengesystemet vil have betydning for, hvordan jeg stemmer ved kommunalvalg og folketingsvalg
                 1= Meget uenig … 5 = Meget enig
-	c5: Jeg vil klage over dårlige oplevelser i systemet
                 1= Meget uenig … 5 = Meget enig
-	c6: Jeg vil deltage aktivt i generalforsamlingerne i min [a-kasses navn, red.]-afdeling
                 1= Meget uenig … 5 = Meget enig

Item a measures willingness to vote at the next parliamentary election.
Items b1-b5 measure trust in different public institutions.
Items c1-c6 measure intentions to democratically participate in different context-specific arenas related to unemployment

5) Hypothesis testing
When analyzing the data, we will compare the recipients responses based on their treatment assignment. Compared to respondents in group 4, we expect that:
1.	Respondents in group 1-3 will be less willing to vote at the next parliamentary election.
2.	Respondents in group 1-3 will exhibit less trust in public institutions.
3.	Respondents in group 1-3 will be less willing to democratically participate in context-specific arenas related to unemployment.

attributes.title: Diagnosing overtraining syndrome: a scoping review protocol
attributes.description: This project aims to conduct a scoping review of the available diagnostic tools for the overtraining syndrome.

summary.value:
Introduction
Overtraining syndrome (OTS) is a medical condition, which can occur in case of an imbalance between training-related or non-training-related load and recovery. Affected athletes need several weeks to months to recover. Therefore, OTS cannot only endanger athletes’ health but also their career. Due to the lack of a gold standard diagnostic tool, OTS is currently a diagnosis of exclusion. Systematic reviewing of reported diagnostic biomarkers and tools for OTS is critical to define such a gold standard diagnostic tool in the future.

Objective
The aims of this scoping review are to systematically review the current literature and to map reported diagnostic biomarkers and tools for OTS.

Inclusion criteria
Studies reporting at least one diagnostic biomarker or tool for OTS and involving human beings affected by OTS according to the definition displayed in the joint consensus statement of the European College of Sport Science (ECSS) and the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) will be considered.

Methods
PubMed, Web of Science, and SportDiscus will be searched for relevant articles. Full-texts of selected abstracts will be independently screened for inclusion by two reviewers. References and citing articles of included articles will be screened for additional relevant publications. Data from included articles will be independently extracted by two reviewers using a pre-specified data extraction form. Results will be presented in narrative, tabulated and/or charted form.

attributes.title: Longitudinal associations between prosocial skills and behavioral problems across childhood

summary.value:
A narrative summary of the project follows below. See the attached word-document for the full preregistration (adjusted from the Social Psychology preregistration of Van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016).

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

A broad range of studies has shown that prosocial skills and behavioral problems are related constructs. Between persons, children and adolescents higher in prosocial skills are usually lower in behavioral problems such as externalizing and internalizing problems (Flynn et al., 2015; Memmott-Elison et al., 2020). These studies indicate that prosocial skills might be a protective factor for developing behavioral problems and therefore several researchers have suggested that prosocial skills might be an interesting target in interventions for behavioral problems. However, little research has been done on within-person changes of prosocial skills and behavioral problems over time. Put otherwise, do changes within a person in one construct affect performance on the other construct? This is a crucial question with respect to intervention planning. To our knowledge, studies investigating this question so far mainly focused on within-person changes during adolescence (Padilla-Walker et al., 2015; Padilla-Walker et al., 2018). For instance, Padilla-Walker et al. (2018) showed that prosocial behavior and aggression were negatively associated bi-directionally over time. However, since prosocial behavior is a relatively stable trait once developed (Nantel-Vivier et al., 2009; Flynn et al., 2015), it might be important to investigate within-person changes in an earlier phase, during childhood. Moreover, until now it remains unclear whether there are sensitive windows for within-person changes. It is often suggested that early intervention (i.e., during early childhood) results in the largest effect. However, one might suggest that middle childhood is a more suitable period for such within-person changes, as this is a developmental phase where the first friendships emerge and prosocial skills become specifically important (Del Giudice et al., 2009; van der Meulen et al., 2018). 

To shed light on these important questions, the current project proposes to use random-intercept cross lagged panel models (RI-CLPM; Hamaker et al. (2015) to investigate within person effects of prosocial skills on behavioral problems (either internalizing or externalizing) and vice versa during childhood, see Figure 1. To obtain robust results, three indicators of prosocial skills will be used: parental report of prosocial skills (SDQ); parental report of empathy (My Child); and costly donating behavior. Within time points we will test how these prosocial skills relate to both internalizing (SDQ subscales emotional problems + peer problems) and externalizing (SDQ subscale conduct problems + hyperactivity) problem behavior. The evidence on the relation between behavior problems and the three measures of prosocial skills will be aggregated by means of Bayesian evidence synthesis (Kuiper et al., 2013; Zondervan et al., 2019). This encompasses that we will use a set of competing informative hypotheses (Hoijtink, 2012), and evaluate which hypothesis receives most support by the data.

attributes.title: Support for equalising vs. enhancing teaching interventions (a study on UK parents)
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
IV 1: SES (measured by education level)
IV 2: Child ability 
IV3: Political orientation
IV4: Intervention type (equalizing vs. enhancing), manipulated, between participants variable. 

It is worth noting that in the present study, the selection context will be maintained constant. Indeed, all participants will be reminded of the importance of school success in determining future success in life.

question2b.value:
The main DV is behavioral support in the implementation of the intervention (ordinal variable, 4 modalities of answers). 
It is worth noting that self-report attitude toward the intervention (6 items) will be measured (as in the previous studies) but only for the credibility of the behavioral support question. Indeed, previous studies raised inconsistent results on this DV and thus, we mostly expect effect on the behavioral support DV.

question10b.value: A file with the complete material is attached.

question4b.value: Participants will be UK participants who have at least one child enrolled in secondary school in UK. A screening question will check this.

question5b.value: 800 participants will be recruited within an online professional platform and will be paid £1 in exchange for their participation.

question6b.value: Most of the effects obtained in previous research using this paradigm are small size effects (f<.11). Power analyses suggest that a sample of N = 649 is required to have 80% chances to detect effects of this size. In addition, we know from the previous studies that we may lose between 6 and 15% of the sample due to missing data or erroneous responses on check variables. Thus, we plan to recruit 800 participants.

question8b.value: Participants who provide absurd answers or no answer to the first open-ended question (“Please summarize the above paragraph in a single sentence (15 word maximum)”) will be removed from the sample.

question9b.value:
Our regression model will include as predictors: SES (undergraduate degree or higher: 0.5 vs. lower level of education: -0.5); mean-centered child academic achievement, mean-centered political orientation, intervention type (-0,5 for equalising intervention; 0,5 for enhancing intervention) and all possible interactions. 
 
This model will be tested on interest (linear regression) and support to the intervention (ordinal regressions).

data.name: FULL_MATERIAL_Support for equalising vs. enhancing teaching interventions .docx

extra.selectedFileName: FULL_MATERIAL_Support for equalising vs. enhancing teaching interventions .docx

question1a.value:
In a previous pre-registered experiment conducted on parents, we expected SES (measured by a subjective SES scale) to negatively predict support for the implementation of an equalising intervention (that reduces the SES achievement gap) at their children's school. Contrary to this hypothesis, in this research, perceived child academic achievement predicted such a support, but subjective SES did not.  
The first goal of the present research is to verify the existence of a negative link between perceived child ability and support (replication).
The second goal is to test the hypothesis that SES negatively predicts support (as initially predicted) but with another (more appropriate) measure of SES: Level of education.
The third goal is to test the moderations of the above effects by two factors: political orientation and intervention type. 
As far as political orientation is concerned, as in the above referenced study, the negative link between child achievement level (CAL) and support for the intervention should be stronger among conservative than among liberal participants. 
As far as intervention type is concerned, in the present study, depending on the condition, participants will be either presented an “equalising intervention” or an “enhancing intervention” (see Darnon, Smeding & Redersdoff, 2018). The negative effects of SES is supposed to be due to the threat that equality represent for higher status individuals. Thus, it is mainly expected to appear for the equalising intervention (but not for the enhancing intervention). For similar reasons, the negative effect of political orientation should be stronger for the equalizing intervention than for the enhancing intervention.

question2a.value:
The three main effect hypotheses are as follow: 
1-	SES (level of education) should negatively affect support for the intervention (main effect of SES)
2-	Perceived CAL should negatively predict support for the intervention (main effect of perceived CAL) 
3-	Political orientation should negatively affect support for the intervention (main effect of Political orientation) 
The 2-way interaction hypothesis are as follow: 
4-	The negative link between CAL and support for the intervention should be stronger among conservative than among liberal participants (interaction political orientationXCAL). 
5-	The negative link between SES and support for the intervention should be stronger for the equalising intervention than for the enhancing intervention (interaction intervention typeXSES).
6-	The negative link between political orientation and support for the intervention should be stronger for the equalizing intervention than for the enhancing intervention (Interaction intervention type X political orientation).

question3a.value: Participants will be asked to report the average performance of low and high SES students before and after the implementation of the bogus ALPHA intervention. Only participants who will adequately report the values (47,5/67,5/82,5/82,5 for the equalising intervention ; 47,5/67,5/62,5/82,5 for the enhancing intervention) will be kept in the analysis. It is worth noting that participants who will report values that are not the exact values but that follow the same pattern (e.g., 48/68/81/81) will also be maintained in the analysis.

question5a.value:
Previous research has shown that the educational system serves a double function in society. On the one hand, the role of the educational system is to teach and educate pupils and students, to elevate their level of competence and knowledge. On the other hand, and in a more subtle way, the educational system serves as a filter for social status. As a matter of fact, this selection function is highly reproductive in the sense that it creates conditions that are favorable to the underachievement of low socioeconomic families. For that reason, the implementation of equalising practices at school may threaten the equilibrium of the system and in particular, the superior position that higher status families occupy within this system.
Previous pre-registered experiments have indicated either that SES, or perceived child achievement level (CAL) negatively predict support for the implementation of an equalising intervention (that reduces the SES achievement gap). 
The first goal of the present research is to verify the existence of a negative link between perceived child ability and support (replication).
The second goal is to test the hypothesis that SES negatively predicts support (as initially predicted) but with another (more appropriate) measure of SES: Level of education.
The third is to test the moderations of the above effects by political orientation and intervention type (see above).

question1c.value:
Our regression model will include as predictors: SES (undergraduate degree or higher: 0.5 vs. lower level of education: -0.5); mean-centered child academic achievement, mean-centered political orientation, intervention type (-0,5 for equalising intervention; 0,5 for enhancing intervention) and all possible interactions. 
 
This model will be tested on interest (linear regression) and support to the intervention (ordinal regressions).

question2c.value: The behavioral support measure had ordered categories rather than continuous scores. Thus, ordinal logistic regression will be used (Long & Freese, 2006).

question1c.value:
It is worth noting that perceived level of economic inequalities will be measured as an additional variable. In exploratory analyses, we will test whether this variable moderates the effects of SES and CAL. Indeed, one could expect these negative links to be particularly pronounced when participants think inequalities in society are large, than when they believe them to be smaller. 
In addition, we will measure SDO. In exploratory analyses, SDO will be tested as a mediator of the effects of SES (and its interaction with intervention type and political orientation) on support.

In the present Study, subjective SES will again be measured but contrary to the previous study, the scale will be reversed so that the higher number (10) corresponds to a low level of subjective SES and lower number (1) to a high subjective SES. In further analyses, we will test the same regression model as above but with “subjective SES” instead of education level as a measure of SES. 
If the two above IV (subjective SES and education level) do not predict the outcome, a final regression model including “income” as a SES variable will be tested on interest and support to the intervention.

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
In a previous pre-registered experiment conducted on parents, we expected SES (measured by a subjective SES scale) to negatively predict support for the implementation of an equalising intervention (that reduces the SES achievement gap) at their children's school. Contrary to this hypothesis, in this research, perceived child academic achievement predicted such a support, but subjective SES did not.  
The first goal of the present research is to verify the existence of a negative link between perceived child ability and support (replication).
The second goal is to test the hypothesis that SES negatively predicts support (as initially predicted) but with another (more appropriate) measure of SES: Level of education.
The third goal is to test the moderations of the above effects by two factors: political orientation and intervention type. 
As far as political orientation is concerned, as in the above referenced study, the negative link between child achievement level (CAL) and support for the intervention should be stronger among conservative than among liberal participants. 
As far as intervention type is concerned, in the present study, depending on the condition, participants will be either presented an “equalising intervention” or an “enhancing intervention” (see Darnon, Smeding & Redersdoff, 2018). The negative effects of SES is supposed to be due to the threat that equality represent for higher status individuals. Thus, it is mainly expected to appear for the equalising intervention (but not for the enhancing intervention). For similar reasons, the negative effect of political orientation should be stronger for the equalizing intervention than for the enhancing intervention.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a:
The three main effect hypotheses are as follow: 
1-	SES (level of education) should negatively affect support for the intervention (main effect of SES)
2-	Perceived CAL should negatively predict support for the intervention (main effect of perceived CAL) 
3-	Political orientation should negatively affect support for the intervention (main effect of Political orientation) 
The 2-way interaction hypothesis are as follow: 
4-	The negative link between CAL and support for the intervention should be stronger among conservative than among liberal participants (interaction political orientationXCAL). 
5-	The negative link between SES and support for the intervention should be stronger for the equalising intervention than for the enhancing intervention (interaction intervention typeXSES).
6-	The negative link between political orientation and support for the intervention should be stronger for the equalizing intervention than for the enhancing intervention (Interaction intervention type X political orientation).

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants will be UK participants who have at least one child enrolled in secondary school in UK. A screening question will check this.
800 participants will be recruited within an online professional platform and will be paid £1 in exchange for their participation.

Most of the effects obtained in previous research using this paradigm are small size effects (f<.11). Power analyses suggest that a sample of N = 649 is required to have 80% chances to detect effects of this size. In addition, we know from the previous studies that we may lose between 6 and 15% of the sample due to missing data or erroneous responses on check variables. Thus, we plan to recruit 800 participants.

attributes.title: Innovative strategies to fight antimicrobial resistance: crowdsourcing to expand medical training
attributes.description: We describe an innovative strategy to tackle the increasing threat of antimicrobial resistance. Many papers have identified decreasing interest in infectious disease training and there are few programmes to build interests in the specialty. We organised a challenge contest soliciting clinical cases to emphasize the role of clinical diagnostics and spur interest in infectious diseases.

summary.value:
This project contains supplementary files for the paper titled: Innovative strategies to fight antimicrobial resistance: crowdsourcing to expand medical training. 
These include Delphi Survey and results, clinical cases and score, judging criteria and promotional banners/flyers.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Secondary analyses --

First, we will test whether there is a significant interaction effect between condition and participant country on our secondary outcome: percentage of the total calories participants believe they need from protein. We will conduct a two-way ANOVA to test this. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05. If a significant condition by country interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct the one-way ANOVA outlined below separately for each country. If a significant condition by country interaction effect does not emerge, then we will conduct the one-way ANOVA outlined below among participants from all three countries together.

For percentage of the total calories participants believe they need from protein, we will conduct a mixed-contrast within a one-way ANOVA to compare meat-morality condition participants’ scores with those of participants in all other conditions together. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05. Second, we will conduct all six possible pairwise comparisons within this ANOVA—Bonferroni-adjusting our significance threshold to p = .008 to avoid an inflated false positive rate—to test, specifically, which of these four conditions differ from one another.

In another set of secondary analyses, we will test for moderation effects. For each moderation, we conduct an ordinary least squares regression to test whether the effect of condition (meat-morality condition versus all three other conditions combined) on the outcome variable is moderated by meat consumption frequency, meat commitment, and/or gender. For gender moderation analyses, we will include only men and women. We will conduct three separate regressions (one for each outcome) to test whether the effect of condition varies across level of gender, three separate regressions (one for each outcome) to test whether the effect of condition varies across levels of meat consumption frequency, and three separate regressions (one for each outcome) to test whether the effect of condition varies across levels of meat commitment. As an example, for testing whether the effect of condition on perceived protein importance varies by gender, we will regress perceived protein importance on gender, condition, and the interaction term for gender and condition. For any of the three outcomes (perceived protein importance, perceived protein inadequacy of vegetarian diets, and percentage of the total calories participants believe they need from protein) for which a significant condition by country interaction effect emerges, we will conduct these moderation tests for gender, meat consumption frequency, and meat commitment separately for each country. For any outcomes for which there is not a significant condition by country interaction effect, we will conduct these moderation tests among participants from all three countries together. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

sample.value: We will recruit 320 participants from the United States, 320 participants from the United Kingdom, and 320 participants from Australia.

analyses.value:
First, we will conduct two sets of analyses (one for each primary outcome— perceived protein importance and perceived protein inadequacy of vegetarian diets) to test whether there is a significant interaction effect between condition and participant country on the outcome. We will conduct two separate two-way analyses of variance (ANOVAs) to test this. One ANOVA will test for an interaction effect between condition and country on perceived protein importance. A second ANOVA will test for an interaction effect between condition and country on perceived protein inadequacy of vegetarian diets. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05. If a significant condition by country interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct the one-way ANOVAs outlined below separately for each country. If a significant condition by country interaction effect does not emerge, then we will conduct the one-way ANOVAs outlined below among participants from all three countries together.

For each of our primary outcomes—perceived protein importance and perceived protein inadequacy of vegetarian diets—we will conduct a mixed-contrast within a one-way ANOVA to compare meat-morality condition participants’ scores with those of participants in all other conditions together. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05. Second, we will conduct all six possible pairwise comparisons within this ANOVA—Bonferroni-adjusting our significance threshold to p = .008 to avoid an inflated false positive rate—to test, specifically, which of these four conditions differ from one another.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan (i.e., if they reply “never” to the consumption frequency questions about both red meat and poultry), fail an attention check in the survey, spend less than 1 minute on the video page of the survey (*this exclusion is pertinent to participants in the 3 video conditions), or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age.

dependent.value:
The first key dependent variable for this study is perceived protein importance, which will be assessed by the following 9 items: “Protein is the most important nutrient in a diet,” “Human beings need to eat a lot of protein in order to stay healthy,” “Eating a lot of protein is essential for building muscle,” “For maintaining a healthy body weight, eating a high-protein diet is better than eating a low-protein diet,” “Eating enough protein is the most important nutritional concern,” “Human beings need to make sure they get enough protein in their diet every day,” “Meals that are high in protein provide the body with strength,” “Most people overemphasize the importance of protein in their diet” (reverse-scored), and “Human beings don’t really need to eat that much protein to stay healthy” (reverse-scored). Responses to all items will range from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 7 (Strongly Agree).

The second key dependent variable is perceived protein inadequacy of vegetarian diets, which will be assessed by the following 5 items: “Vegetarian diets cannot provide enough protein,” “If I were to give up eating meat, I could never get enough protein,” “Following a vegetarian diet would provide me with more than enough protein to stay healthy” (reverse-scored), “Vegetarians are at high risk for becoming protein deficient,” and “Eating meat is essential for consuming enough protein.” Responses to all items will range from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 7 (Strongly Agree).

A third dependent variable is the percentage of the total calories in their diet that participants believe they need to come from protein, which will be assessed by the following question: “What is the minimum percentage of the calories you consume that need to come from protein?” The response scale for this question will be a slider ranging from 0% to 100%.

The independent variable for this study is our experimental prime, which includes four conditions, each of which will be operationalized by a short video. Participants across the four conditions will either (1) watch a video that depicts the negative ways in which animals used for meat are treated (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cVWpI2cdhGQ&has_verified=1), (2) watch a video that depicts the negative ways in which child slaves sometimes used in conventional chocolate production on cacao farms are treated (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eHDxy04QPqM), (3) watch a video of a chef cooking meat (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AmC9SmCBUj4), or (4) not watch any video.

Gender will be assessed by the item, “Please select your gender,” with responses including “Man,” “Woman,” “Non-Binary,” and “Other.”

Meat consumption frequency will be assessed by 2 questions: “How often do you eat red meat (i.e., beef, pork, etc.)?” and “How often do you eat poultry (i.e., chicken, turkey, etc.)?” Responses to each of these questions (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) will include never (1), a few times per year (2), once per month (3), a few times per month (4), once per week (5), 2 to 3 days per week (6), 4 to 6 days per week (7), 1 meal per day (8), 2 meals per day (9), and 3 or more meals per day (10). Meat consumption frequency will be operationalized as the average of scores on these two questions.

Meat commitment will be assessed by Piazza et al.’s (2015) meat commitment scale. The 7 items on this scale are “I don’t want to eat meals without meat,” “When choosing food, I virtually always select the meat option,” “I can’t imagine giving up meat,” “I am committed to eating meat,” “The best part of most meals is the meat portion,” “I would never give up eating meat,” and “I cannot imagine substituting meat from a meal.” Responses to all items will range from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 7 (Strongly Agree).

conditions.value: There are four conditions in this survey: meat-morality, morality-control, meat-control, and neutral control.

hypothesis.value:
The purpose of this study is to investigate whether people amplify the importance of dietary protein as a strategy for managing the morally troublesome implications of eating meat. We hypothesize that having participants consider the moral implications of eating meat—for example, that farm animals used for meat often suffer in poor conditions—will cause them (1) to perceive protein as a more important part of their diets and (2) to perceive vegetarian diets as less adequate for providing sufficient protein. These are our two primary hypotheses. A secondary hypothesis is that having participants consider the moral implications of eating meat will cause them to report that a higher percentage of the total calories in their diet need to come from protein.

Our study will include four conditions: (1) meat-morality, (2) morality-control (i.e., food morality unrelated to meat), (3) meat-control (i.e., meat unrelated to morality), or (4) neutral-control (i.e., no content). We hypothesize specifically that people in the meat-morality condition will perceive protein to be a more important part of their diets, perceive vegetarian diets as less adequate for providing sufficient protein, and report that a higher percentage of the total calories in their diet need to come from protein than will participants in the other conditions. We will test three moderators: meat consumption frequency, meat commitment, and gender. We hypothesize moderation by meat consumption frequency, such that the effects of priming meat morality on each of our three outcomes will be larger at higher levels of meat consumption frequency than at lower levels. We hypothesize moderation by meat commitment, such that the effects of priming meat morality on each of our three outcomes will be larger at higher levels of meat commitment than at lower levels. We set no directional hypothesis for the moderating effects of gender.

q1.value: Deconstructing Psychosis and Cross-Validating the R-PAS Variables Targeting its Constructs

q2.value: Kirsten Buckingham, Joni L Mihura, Gregory J. Meyer

q3.value: The current study assesses the relationship between R-PAS measures (e.g. WSumCog, Complexity, FQ-%, M-, SPCT, PEC) and BPRS and SCID-III-P (1989 version for DSM-III-R) measures of disorganized thinking, negative symptoms, delusions, and hallucinations. These relationships will be analyzed using an archival clinical sample of 70 patients with schizophrenia, schizoaffective, and major depressive disorder. Specifically, we expect to replicate previous research showing clinician ratings of disorganized thinking in relationship with R-PAS WSumCog and demonstrate that a new dimensionalized measure of disorganized thinking (SPCT) will provide incremental prediction of the BPRS Conceptual Disorganization and SCID-P disorganized thinking criteria over the traditional R-PAS measure (WSumCog). In addition, we predict that that negative symptoms from the BPRS and SCID-P will correlate in expected directions with R-PAS measures of behavioral, perceptual and emotional task engagement (Complexity & FQ-%). We anticipate that measures of delusional criteria on the BPRS and the SCID-P criteria will correlate with R-PAS measures of inaccurate understanding of human intention and action (M-) as well as illogical thinking (Peculiar Logic and SPCT Illogical Thinking). Further, we predict that clinician ratings of hallucinations on the BPRS and SCID-P will correlate positively with an R-PAS measure of visual misperceptions (FQ-%). Additionally, a t-test will be conducted to evaluate the R-PAS TPMZ for differences between the patients with psychotic (schizoaffective and schizophrenia) diagnoses and depression diagnoses.

q4.value:
Directional hypotheses: 
(i)	The composite of BPRS Conceptual Disorganization and SCID-P Schizophrenia items (Incoherence and Marked Loosening of Associations) will correlate positively with R-PAS WSumCog but, using hierarchical regression analyses, SPCT Total will predict additional variance over and above WSumCog. 
(ii)	The composite of 3 BPRS items (Blunted Affect, Emotional Withdrawal, Motor Retardation) and the SCID-P Catatonic and Flat Affect items will correlate negatively with R-PAS Complexity and positively with FQ-%. 
(iii)	The composite of the BPRS Unusual Thought Content and the SCID-P delusion criteria (Delusions of Reference, Persecutory Delusions, Grandiose Delusions, Somatic Delusions, Other Delusions, Delusions of being controlled, Thought Broadcasting, Systematized Delusions, Bizarre Delusions) will correlate positively with R-PAS M- and Peculiar Logic and the SPCT Illogical Thinking. 
(iv)	The composite of BPRS Hallucinatory Behavior and SCID-P hallucinatory criteria (Auditory Hallucinations, Visual Hallucinations, Tactile Hallucinations, and Other Hallucinations) will correlate positively with FQ-%. 
(v)	TPMZ will differentiate between psychotic and non-psychotic patients.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: The predictor (Rorschach) raters were blind to the criterion (BPRS and SCID) ratings; clinicians collecting the criterion data were blind to Rorschach data. The Rorschach, BPRS, and SCID reliability raters were also both blind to each other’s ratings. The human subjects were blind to the study hypotheses.

question.value: Data were collected at the Palo Alto VA center as part of an IRB-approved research project that utilized a cross-sectional design, but ultimately ended in early termination due to lack of funding. We are utilizing a correlational design.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The 70 subjects for the study were obtained from the Inpatient Treatment Unit (ITU; building 324) at the Menlo Park division of the Palo Alto Veterans Administration Medical Center in 1992. The data consist of clinician ratings on the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) and Structured Interview for DSM-III-R - Patient Version (SCID-P), as well as responses to the Rorschach task. The patients have diagnoses of schizophrenia, schizoaffective, and major depressive disorder. I do not have access to any information regarding patterns, summary statistics, or previous analyses; no prior analyses have been conducted with these data. I have yet to analyze the data myself. I currently have access to the predictor data (i.e., Rorschach responses), which I am coding, and the criterion variable data, which I am entering into an SPSS file. However, I am blind to individual patients, as each dataset uses different identifiers and I do not have the key that links them.

question.value: The subjects for the study were obtained from the Inpatient Treatment Unit (ITU; building 324) at the Menlo Park division of the Palo Alto Veterans Administration Medical Center. Participants had diagnoses of schizophrenia, schizoaffective, and major depression without psychotic features. Exclusionary criteria for the initial study included history of central nervous system disease, head trauma, and inability to follow simple instructions. Subjects were recruited from 3 inpatient psychiatric wards and received no form of compensation. Normal control subjects were to be collected from staff volunteers in the ITU, but the study ended early due to lack of funding. A total of 75 patients were initially enrolled in the study; five of the 75 patients did not complete the study.

q13.value: 70 participants (22 with schizophrenia, 28 with schizoaffective disorder, and 20 with major depression)

q14.value: Using everything available to me through an archival data set.

q15.value: Using everything available to me through an archival data set.

question.value: Most of the analyses use a correlational design. One analysis relies on criterion variable groups based on the patients’ diagnoses.

Rorschach variables: FQ-, M-, SPCT Total, SPCT IVJ, TPMZ, Complexity, PEC, and WSumCog. 

Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) items: Conceptual Disorganization, Unusual Thought Content, Hallucinatory Behavior, Blunted affect, Emotional Withdrawal, and Motor Retardation. 

Structured Interview for DSM (SCID) criteria: Delusions of Reference, Persecutory Delusions, Grandiose Delusions, Somatic Delusions, Other Delusions, Delusions of being controlled, Thought Broadcasting, Systematized Delusions, Bizarre Delusions, Auditory Hallucinations, Visual Hallucinations, Tactile Hallucinations, Other Hallucinations, Catatonic Behavior, Flat Affect, Incoherence, Marked Loosening of Associations
We are creating indices (components) from the SCID criteria and from the SCID and BPRS. All of the R-PAS measures are standardized.

Interrater reliability will be computed for all variables. We will compute interrater reliability of the R-PAS, SCID-P, and BPRS ratings using single rater exact agreement ICCs with the benchmarks Poor <.40, Fair = .40-.59, Good = .60-.74, Excellent ≥.75. For the R-PAS ratings, because the same 2 raters coded the responses for all scores, a two-way random effects model will be used. For the SCID-P and BPRS, because the same 2 raters did not code all of the responses, a one-way random effects model will be used. A statistical measure of skewness will be used to describe and evaluate the distributions; variables with problematic skew > 2.0 will be square root transformed. When items are averaged to form a single variable, z-score transformations will be performed before the variables are averaged. 
Correlational analyses will be conducted to test the relationship between clinician ratings of disorganized thinking (BPRS Conceptual Disorganization and relevant SCID criteria) and the traditional measure of disorganized thinking on R-PAS, WSumCog. We will then use hierarchical regression analyses to determine whether the new dimensionalized measure of disorganized thinking, SPCT, provides incremental prediction over WSumCog.If the r for WSumCog is higher than the r for SPCT, we will examine incremental validity for WSumCog. 
We will compute the mean of the SCID items Incoherence and Marked Loosening of Associations, convert that mean to a z score, and average that z score with the z score of BPRS Conceptual Disorganization. We will compute the mean from the SCID-P Catatonic and Flat Affect items, convert it to a z score, and then average it with the mean z score from the BPRS items Blunted Affect, Emotional Withdrawal, and Motor Retardation. We will run a component analysis of the SCID-P delusional items, extract the first principal component, save the factor score, and then average it with the BPRS z score for Unusual Thought Content. We will run a component analysis with the SCID-P hallucinatory items; extract the first principal component, save the factor score, and combine it with the BPRS z score for Hallucinatory Behavior by averaging the values.
	A t-test will be conducted to evaluate the R-PAS TPMZ for differences between the patients with psychotic (schizoaffective and schizophrenia) diagnoses and depression diagnoses.
To replicate previous research, we will test the relationship between negative symptom ratings (on the BPRS and SCID) and R-PAS measures of behavioral, perceptual, and emotional task engagement (Complexity & FQ-%). Further, we anticipate that clinician ratings of delusions (on the BPRS and the SCID) will correlate with R-PAS measures of inaccurate understanding of human intention and action (M-) and illogical thinking (SPCT Illogical Thinking subscale). Lastly, we use correlational analyses to test the relationship between clinician ratings of hallucinations (on the BPRS and SCID) and an R-PAS measure of visual misperceptions (FQ-%).

q20.value:
A transformation for problematic skewness will be computed as R-PAS scores have a low base rate. A square root transformation will be conducted for variables that have a skew of more than 2. If problematic skew remains, the variable will be winsorized.
We will use percentage scores for the Rorschach variables to account for differences in the number of responses.

q21.value: Two-tailed test. We will be using a p value of 0.05.

q22.value: We will screen the data for data entry errors. For other outliers, we will apply a skew correction first, then will winsorize the data point if necessary. We will only exclude patients who lack the relevant predictor or criterion variables.

q23.value: In this data set, most ratings were done by two clinicians (on SCID and BPRS). We will average their ratings regardless of whether either set of ratings is missing or not. Any missing item level data that remains will be treated as missing (i.e., we do not plan to use multiple imputation).

q24.value: We will look at the subcomponents of the SPCT to evaluate if the DCC subscale carries the most weight, as it did in one prior study.

attributes.title: Put a label on it: Knowledge of hapa label promotes multiracial categorizations

q1.value: Put a label on it: Knowledge of hapa label promotes multiracial categorizations (Study 2)

q2.value: Jonathan Benitez, Debbie S. Ma, Justin Kantner, Stephanie Dunn

q3.value: Categorizations of multiracial individuals are more difficult for perceivers to make and take more time (Blascovich, Wyer, Swart, & Kibler, 1997). Previous research has shown that when people are given the option to classify a multiracial Asian-White individual as either Asian, White, or multiracial, the multiracial option is rarely used (Chen & Hamilton, 2012). Perceivers accurately categorize both Asian and White monoracial individuals at far above chance levels (Chen & Hamilton, 2012). However, multiracial individuals are accurately categorized only slightly above chance (Chen et al., 2018). Existing research has demonstrated that the use of labels facilitates accurate categorizations of that group (Lupyan, 2006). Importantly, the labels that we learn as part of our language are what we use to make sense of the world (Lupyan, Rakison, & McClelland, 2007). The purpose of this study is to determine whether learning a new label (i.e., hapa) for Asian-White multiracial individuals will promote multiracial categorization accuracy.

q4.value: We wish to determine if there is a difference in participant’s race categorizations when an Asian-White multiracial label (hapa) is learned versus a control group. Based on prior research on category labels, we predict that participants who learn the new label will have more multiracial categorizations than the control group (Lupyan, 2006). A third condition, using the term “Asian-White multiracial” will also be included. We expect that knowledge of the hapa label will result in the greatest amount of concordant multiracial categorizations, followed up by the Asian-White multiracial condition, and finally, the control condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will have a one-way between-subjects design. There will be three conditions. In all three conditions, participants will read an article from National Public Radio (NPR). In the first condition, the article will describe the “hapa” label to participants (i.e., a label used in Hawaii to describe Asian-White multiracial individuals). In the second condition, participants will read the same article with the phrase “Asian-White multiracial individuals”. In the third (control) condition, participants will be told, in an article, that “hapa” means something else entirely (i.e., a new type of fish). After reading the article, all participants will be asked to categorize a set of multiracial stimuli according to race. Each condition will have an equivalent number of monoracial stimuli to keep the purpose of the study hidden. We also want to include monoracial stimuli so that we have a baseline against which to compare the multiracial stimuli.

q9.value: The participants will be randomly placed in each condition with the randomize option on Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We are collecting our data using workers from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk. Our sample will be taken from the U.S. population. We will collect data over the course of two days. We will use an awareness/attention check to exclude participants who are clearly not paying enough attention to the questions in the study.

q13.value: Based on a power analysis, our sample size will be 250 U.S. based participants.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis in G*Power for an ANOVA (Fixed effects, omnibus, one-way) with an effect size of 0.25 and power of 0.9 and found we would need 207 participants. Because we plan to exclude participants who fail a captcha or provide incomplete data, we will include more participants, for a total of 250.

question.value: There will be three conditions with three different articles. In the first condition, the article will describe the “hapa” label to participants (i.e., a label used in Hawaii to describe Asian-White multiracial individuals). In the second condition, participants will read the same article with the phrase “Asian-White multiracial individuals”. In the third condition, participants will be told, in an article, that “hapa” means something else entirely (i.e., a new type of fish).

The only DV will be race categorization. There are 9 options for the participants to choose from: White, Latino/Hispanic, Black, Asian, Pacific Islander, Native American, Middle Eastern, Other, or Biracial/Multiracial.

We plan to run an ANOVA will follow-up pairwise comparisons. The independent variable will be article condition (hapa, Asian-White multiracial, control) and the dependent variable will be racial categorization. We will also run one-sample t-tests against chance levels for each racial group, across both conditions. 

Due to the multilevel nature of our data, in our supplementary material, we plan to include a multilevel multinomial logistic regression model. The model will include article condition (hapa, Asian-White multiracial, control) as a fixed factor, participant and stimuli as random factors, and racial categorization as the multinomial outcome variable. If the conclusions from these analyses differ from those of the t-tests, we will fully disclose this information.

q21.value: A alpha level of .05 will be used to make statistical inferences. We will use two-tailed tests for all of our analyses.

q22.value: We plan to exclude any incomplete data. We will only remove participants who did not provide proper attention to the experiment (i.e. 90% of the responses are the same). We will include an awareness check. Participants who failed the awareness check will be excluded from the analyses.

q23.value: If a participant provides incomplete data, then we will remove the entire case from the data set.

The independent variable will be article condition (hapa, Asian-White multiracial, control) and the dependent variable will be racial categorization. We will also run one-sample t-tests against chance levels for each racial group, across both conditions. 

Due to the multilevel nature of our data, in our supplementary material, we plan to include a multilevel multinomial logistic regression model. The model will include article condition (hapa, Asian-White multiracial, control) as a fixed factor, participant and stimuli as random factors, and racial categorization as the multinomial outcome variable. If the conclusions from these analyses differ from those of the t-tests, we will fully disclose this information.

attributes.title: Put a label on it: Knowledge of hapa label promotes multiracial categorizations

q1.value: Put a label on it: Knowledge of hapa label promotes multiracial categorizations (Study 1)

q2.value: Jonathan Benitez, Debbie S. Ma, Justin Kantner, Stephanie Dunn

q3.value: Categorizations of multiracial individuals are more difficult for perceivers to make and take more time (Blascovich, Wyer, Swart, & Kibler, 1997). Previous research has shown that when people are given the option to classify a multiracial Asian-White individual as either Asian, White, or multiracial, the multiracial option is rarely used (Chen & Hamilton, 2012). Perceivers accurately categorize both Asian and White monoracial individuals at far above chance levels (Chen & Hamilton, 2012). However, multiracial individuals are accurately categorized only slightly above chance (Chen et al., 2018). Existing research has demonstrated that the use of labels facilitates accurate categorizations of that group (Lupyan, 2006). Importantly, the labels that we learn as part of our language are what we use to make sense of the world (Lupyan, Rakison, & McClelland, 2007). The purpose of this study is to determine whether knowledge of an existing label (i.e., hapa) for Asian-White multiracial individuals will promote multiracial categorization accuracy.

q4.value: We wish to determine if there is a difference in participant’s race categorizations when participants have existing knowledge of an Asian-White multiracial label (hapa) versus no prior knowledge. Based on existing research on category labels, we predict that participants who have knowledge of the lab will have more multiracial categorizations than those who don’t (Lupyan, 2006). If the majority of participants are unfamiliar with the label, then we hope to conduct a follow-up study where we teach the category label.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is non-experimental. We plan to have participants define a list of words, one of them being “hapa”. Those who have preexisting knowledge of the word will then be compared to those who do not. After defining the list of words including hapa, all participants will be asked to categorize a set of multiracial stimuli according to race. There will be an equivalent number of monoracial stimuli to keep the purpose of the study hidden. We also want to include monoracial stimuli so that we establish a baseline against which to compare the multiracial stimuli.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We are collecting our data using workers from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk. Our sample will be taken from the U.S. population. We will collect data over the course of two days. We will use an awareness/attention check to exclude participants who are clearly not paying enough attention to the questions in the study.

q13.value: Based on a power analysis, our sample size will be 175 U.S. based participants.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis in G*Power for means: difference between two dependent means (matched pairs, two-tailed) (a less complex model compared to multilevel models) with an effect size of 0.25 and power of 0.9 (std at 1 for x and y) and found that we would need 171 participants. We expect to lose a few participants due to incomplete surveys or failure of the attention check.

question.value: No variables will be manipulated. This study is strictly observational.

To use as a predictor, we will measure participants’ knowledge of the term hapa. The main DV will be race categorization. There are 9 options for the participants to choose from: White, Latino/Hispanic, Black, Asian, Pacific Islander, Native American, Middle Eastern, Other, or Biracial/Multiracial.

We will also ask participants for demographic information.

We plan to run a t-test comparing the two groups (knowledge of the hapa term and not). The dependent variable will be racial categorization. We will also run one-sample t-tests against chance levels for each racial group, across both conditions. 

Due to the multilevel nature of our data, in our supplementary material, we plan to include a multilevel multinomial logistic regression model. The model will include hapa knowledge as a fixed factor, participant and stimuli as random factors, and racial categorization as the multinomial outcome variable. If the conclusions from these analyses differ from those of the t-test, we will fully disclose this information.

q21.value: A alpha level of .05 will be used to make statistical inferences. We will use two-tailed tests for all of our analyses.

q22.value: We plan to exclude any incomplete data. We will only remove participants who did not provide proper attention to the experiment (i.e. 90% of the responses are the same). We will include an awareness check. Participants who failed the awareness check will be excluded from the analyses.

q23.value: If a participant provides incomplete data, then we will remove the entire case from the data set.
